In the collection framework when creating a sorted set a Comparator is
pass=
ed in as an argument.  If the Comparator argument is null the
compareTo() o=
n the elements is called.

I am not sure what use an assertGreaterThan( Col=
lection, Collection)
makes much sense.   In mathematics it's not possible t=
o say one vector
is greater than another, unless they are projected onto a =
given axis.
This is not really possible on your average collection of objec=
ts.

I think the only two useful cases are...

assertEquals(Collection, Col=
lection);
assertEquals(Collection, Collection, Comparator );

Passing in a =
null Comparator to the second method would behave like when
passing a Compa=
rator to a sorted set, equals() method (or compareTo())
would be called on =
the elements.  


Dave

You are right.  And as I recall, we have tested for that case in our=

code as
well.  How would the framework know when to use a comparator or no=
t?
Have
something like the following?  Seems quirky... but this is what wor=
king
on 4
hours of sleep can do :)

assertEquals(expectedCollection, actual=
Collection)
assertComparesGreaterThanZero(expectedCollection, actualCollect=
ion)
assertComparesLessThanZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
asser=
tComparesZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)

-Jason

ressed by

  =
